{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"[ Name of plaintiff ]’s disorder is commonly described as having three stages, labeled I, II, and III, in which stage III indicates the most advanced disease. The stages are based primarily on the level of a blood protein secreted by abnormal plasma cells and the level of calcium in the bloodstream, as well as kidney function and anemia measurements. The blood protein level is measured by performing a test that looks for a single abnormal type of antibody in a patient’s blood serum or urine. This protein is referred to as a monoclonal protein or M protein. The stages are identiﬁed as follows: Stage I is present if the patient has: 1) M protein level of 3 grams per deciliter or higher in blood serum and/or 2) A level of 1 gram or higher in a 24-hour urine test; and low calcium levels, normal kidney function, and no anemia. Stage II is present if the patient has: 1) M protein level of less than 3 grams per deciliter in blood serum and 2) a level of less than 1 gram in a 24-hour urine test; or the patient meets criteria for neither stage I nor stage III. Stage III is present if the patient has: 1) M protein level of 5 grams per deciliter or higher in blood serum and/or 2) A level of 3 grams or higher in a 24-hour urine test; and high calcium levels. The stage classiﬁcation may be used to determine how certain medications work based upon the progression of the disorder. Furthermore, you may consider testimony based on these criteria in helping you determine the opinions of experts regarding any issue in this case, including whether the stage of [ name of plaintiff ]’s disorder at a particular time was a substantial factor in causing [his/her/ nonbinary pronoun ] harm.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Doctors diagnose non-small cell lung cancer with a biopsy. A sample of abnormal tissue is removed from the lung and examined under a microscope for cancer cells. There are several ways to obtain a lung tissue sample: • Sputum cytology. If a patient has a cough that produces sputum (mucus from the lungs), the mucus may be checked for cancer cells. This test is not used very often. • Needle biopsy. A thin needle is inserted through the chest wall and into the lung to remove tissue for testing. This is called a transthoracic needle biopsy . • Bronchoscopy. A thin, ﬂexible tube (called a bronchoscope) is inserted through the mouth or nose into the windpipe and lungs. The physician looks through the bronchoscope for abnormal areas and removes tissue samples. • Thoracoscopy. For this test, a small incision (cut) is made between the ribs, and a telescope-like tube is inserted into the chest to examine the lungs and chest cavity. • Thoracotomy. This is a surgical procedure in which a larger cut is made between the ribs, and the lung is partially collapsed so the doctor can examine it and remove a tissue sample. • Mediastinoscopy. This procedure is used to check lymph nodes in the area between the lungs (the mediastinum). A small cut is made near the breastbone, and a thin, ﬂexible tube with a camera (called a mediastinoscope) is inserted to examine the lymph nodes and remove a tissue sample. Once it has been conﬁrmed that the lung cancer is non-small cell lung cancer, the cancer must be staged, or evaluated to determine its extent in the body. Staging is used to help select the best treatment.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Your doctor may suspect lung cancer based on your symptoms and test results. Non-small cell lung cancer can cause several general symptoms such as cough, chest pain, and shortness of breath, as well as other symptoms such as unexplained weight loss. These symptoms can also be caused by other conditions. Your doctor will ask about your symptoms, your history of tobacco and vaping product use, potential exposure to lung cancer risk factors such as radon and secondhand smoke, and will perform a physical examination. If your doctor suspects lung cancer, they will order tests. It is important to detect lung cancer early because it is easier to treat before it spreads. The following tests and procedures may be used to diagnose NSCLC: • Chest x-ray . This procedure creates pictures of the inside of the chest. • Computed tomography (CT) scan . This procedure uses a computer linked to an x-ray machine to create a series of detailed pictures of the inside of the body. • Sputum cytology . If you are coughing up sputum, examining the sputum under a microscope can sometimes show the presence of lung cancer cells. However, a negative sputum cytology test does not rule out lung cancer. • Biopsy . In a biopsy, a tissue sample is removed for examination under a microscope. The sample can be obtained by bronchoscopy, needle biopsy, or surgery. To perform a bronchoscopy, your doctor passes a thin, ﬂexible tube with a light and camera (bronchoscope) down your throat and through your windpipe. Needle biopsy is done by using x-rays or CT scans to guide a needle through your chest wall and into the lung mass or lymph nodes. During surgery, your doctor opens the chest wall to look for signs of disease and to take tissue samples. The biopsy is the best way to tell if the abnormal growth is cancer or another condition, such as an infection or scar tissue.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Small cell lung cancer is diagnosed by a health care professional. Small cell lung cancer is usually diagnosed after a patient develops symptoms and visits a health care professional. Risk factors such as a person’s smoking history, lung cancer symptoms, and the results of a physical examination and diagnostic tests are taken into consideration. Medical history and physical examination If lung cancer is suspected, the health care professional will ask about symptoms and risk factors, including tobacco exposure. A thorough physical examination is then performed. Chest X-ray If a person has symptoms and risk factors for lung cancer, one of the initial tests will usually be a chest X-ray. A chest X-ray may show a suspicious mass in the lungs, but this test cannot determine if the mass is cancerous.  Computed tomography (CT) scan After the chest X-ray, a CT scan is often the next test performed. The scan produces detailed cross-sectional images of the body. The CT scan helps further evaluate chest abnormalities shown on a chest X-ray. It may also help determine if the cancer has spread to other parts of the body. Sputum cytology examination  A sample of sputum may be examined under a microscope by a pathologist to look for cancer cells. This test is most useful for lung cancers that have spread to the larger airways. Tissue biopsy A biopsy is the removal of a small amount of tissue for examination under a microscope by a pathologist to determine if cancer cells are present. The pathologist may run additional tests on the biopsy sample to help ﬁnd the best treatment for the patient. There are many different techniques for obtaining a biopsy sample, including: Fine needle aspiration biopsy  A thin needle is guided through the chest wall into the lung mass to withdraw a small amount of tissue for examination. This procedure is usually performed by a radiologist [a doctor specializing in medical imaging, US] or pulmonologist [lung specialist]. It is often performed using a CT or ultrasound scan to guide placement of the needle. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) biopsy  Using ultrasound along with a bronchoscope , a specially trained pulmonologist inserts a ﬂexible viewing instrument (bronchoscope) through the mouth or nose and down into the lungs. The ultrasound guides the physician as a small needle is inserted through the wall of the airway into a lymph node to collect a sample. Fluorescence bronchoscopy  A bronchoscope with a special blue light is used to visually examine the lining of the airways. These areas can also be biopsied during the procedure. Narrow band imaging  Specially designed bronchoscopes called “SlimScopeTM” and “SuperDimensionTM” have been developed to better identify malignant lesions. Suspected cancerous lesions light up when illuminated by blue-green light. The lesions can also be biopsied during this procedure. Surgical biopsy  During thoracoscopy  or thoracotomy , a surgeon removes a small part of the lung or a lymph node for examination. Thoracoscopy (video-assisted thoracic surgery or VATS) is a minimally invasive procedure in which a surgeon operates through several small incisions in the chest using a tiny camera and specialized instruments. Thoracotomy is an open surgical procedure with a single large incision that allows direct access to the chest organs. After examining the tissue, a pathologist can usually determine whether lung cancer is present as well as identify the lung cancer cell type.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Rectal cancer is described as stage 0, I, II, III, or IV. The lower the stage, the less the cancer has spread. The higher the stage, the more the cancer has spread. Stage 0 is also called carcinoma in situ. It is not really cancer because it has not grown beyond the innermost lining of the rectum. In stage IV, the cancer has spread to another part of the body, such as the lungs or liver.  Stage I  The cancer has grown through the innermost lining of the rectum and into or through the wall of the rectum but has not spread to nearby lymph nodes or other sites.  Stage II  Stage II cancer may have grown through the wall of the rectum and into nearby tissue, but it has not spread to lymph nodes or other sites. Some stage II rectal cancers have grown through the rectum and into or around organs and structures near the rectum. These include the prostate, bladder, vagina, uterus, cervix, or back wall of the pelvis.  Stage III  In stage III, the cancer has spread to nearby lymph nodes but has not spread to other parts of the body.  Stage IV  The cancer has spread to other parts of the body, such as the lungs or liver.  Rectal cancer may also be described using the TNM system. This system is used to further deﬁne each stage of rectal cancer.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The stages of rectal cancer range from stage 0 through stage IV. The stages provide a common language for describing the amount of cancer in the body, including whether the cancer has spread and where it has spread. Your doctor will determine the stage of your cancer after diagnostic tests and surgery. Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) In stage 0, abnormal cells are found in the innermost lining of the rectum. These cells may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue. Stage 0 is also called carcinoma in situ .  Stage 1 In stage 1, the cancer has grown through the innermost lining of the rectum wall but has not spread outside the rectum wall to nearby tissues, lymph nodes, or distant sites. Stage 2 In stage 2, the cancer has grown through the outermost layers of the rectum and may have spread to nearby tissues. It has not spread to nearby lymph nodes or distant sites. Stage 2 is divided into three substages:  Stage 2A—The cancer has grown through the inner and outer layers of the rectum wall but has not spread to nearby tissues, lymph nodes, or distant sites. Stage 2B—The cancer has grown through the outermost layer of the rectum and into nearby tissues, but it has not spread to nearby lymph nodes or distant sites. Stage 2C—The cancer has grown through the outermost layer of the rectum and into nearby organs or structures, but it has not spread to nearby lymph nodes or distant sites. Stage 3 In stage 3, the cancer may have grown through the outermost layers of the rectal wall and into nearby tissues and organs. It has spread to 1 to 12 nearby lymph nodes , but it has not spread to distant sites. Stage 3 is divided into four substages:  Stage 3A—The cancer has grown through the innermost and outermost layers of the rectum wall. It has spread to 1 to 3 nearby lymph nodes, but not to distant sites. Stage 3B—The cancer has grown through the innermost and outermost layers of the rectum wall. It has spread to 4 to 12 nearby lymph nodes, but not to distant sites. Stage 3C—The cancer has grown through the innermost and outermost layers of the rectum wall and into other nearby tissues or organs. It has spread to 1 to 3 nearby lymph nodes, but not to distant sites. Stage 3D—The cancer has grown through the innermost and outermost layers of the rectal wall and into other nearby tissues or organs. It has spread to 4 to 12 nearby lymph nodes, but not to distant sites. Stage 4 In stage 4, the cancer has spread to distant lymph nodes or to distant parts of the body, including the liver, lungs, or lining of the abdominal cavity. Stage 4 is divided into two substages:  Stage 4A—The cancer has spread to one distant part of the body, such as the liver or lungs. Stage 4B—The cancer has spread to more than one distant part of the body or to distant lymph nodes.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Although there is no certain way to prevent colorectal cancer, you can take steps that might lower your risk: • Get screened for colorectal cancer. These foods are high in ﬁber and contain many vitamins and minerals that might help lower the risk of colorectal cancer. • Limit red meat and avoid processed meats. Eating large amounts of these foods is linked to colorectal cancer. • Exercise. Regular physical activity might lower your risk. Aim for at least 2 ½ hours of moderate aerobic activity (such as brisk walking) every week, plus muscle-strengthening activities two or more days a week. • Maintain a healthy weight. Overweight and obesity increase the risk of many cancers, including colorectal cancer. • Limit alcohol use. If you choose to drink alcohol, do so in moderation. • Don’t use tobacco. Talk with your doctor about ways to help you quit. • Ask your doctor about the risks and beneﬁts of aspirin. Some research suggests that daily use of low-dose aspirin might lower the risk of colorectal cancer in certain people. However, aspirin can also increase the risk of serious bleeding inside the stomach and intestines. prompt: How to diagnose Bilateral perisylvian polymicrogyria ?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Bilateral perisylvian polymicrogyria is classically diagnosed in childhood based on clinical and neuroimaging features. Clinical Features  Bilateral perisylvian polymicrogyria presents with the following cardinal features:  • Orofacial muscle weakness and motor speech disorder (dysarthria);  • Epilepsy;  • Pseudobulbar paresis associated with corticobulbar involvement;  • Variable degrees of cognitive impairment.  Neuroimaging  Brain MRI is required to identify the abnormalities characteristic of polymicrogyria. These abnormalities consist of:  • Too many small and abnormal gyri, most easily seen on sagittal and coronal magnetic resonance images;  • Abnormally thick cortex (thickness between 3 and 10 mm);  • A blurring of the gray–white matter junction;  • Abnormal signal involving the cortex and extending slightly into the subcortical white matter;  • Small, malformed and/or heterotropic basal ganglia and hypoplastic brainstem and cerebellar vermis are also frequently present. Secondary features consisting of ventriculomegaly and a dysmorphic thalamus may be seen.  Genetic Testing  Testing is unavailable for most Bilateral perisylvian polymicrogyria . However, couple of genes have been identiﬁed. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Symptoms of Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome may include the following: Hair Follicle Tumors  [Noncancerous tumors that develop on the hair follicles.] Benign skin tumors may develop on the face, neck, and upper torso, including on the nose and ears. prompt: What are the treatments for familial adenomatous polyposis ?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Considerable controversy exists regarding the proper treatment of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). Many surgeons advocate total colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis. This procedure may minimize the development of colon cancer, but does not eliminate rectal cancer, which occurs in 10% to 30% of patients after this operation. Rectal preservation is preferred if the patient is to have a child  because the infertility rate is increased after proctectomy. Total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch–anal anastomosis is used when the number and distribution of rectal polyps preclude the use of the rectum and allow normal sphincter function to be preserved. Secondary analyses of the National Polyp Study data reveal that the risk of colorectal cancer among ﬁrst-degree relatives of individuals with FAP was only 4.7, suggesting that FAP should be only a secondary consideration in managing this group once the gene diagnosis has been made (  Am J Gastroenterol . 1998;93:97).","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Of the various cells in the pancreas, only the islet cells produce insulin. Researchers have learned how to extract islet cells from the pancreas of cadavers, purify them, and inject them into the livers of people with type 1 diabetes. A barrier to this promising treatment is the shortage of donor pancreases. Other hurdles include ensuring that the islet cells will not be rejected by the immune system and that they will survive in the new body. Transplanted islets require that immune suppression drugs be taken continuously. They do not usually restore the production of insulin to normal. But the treatment has helped many people to keep their blood sugar under control and avoid insulin injections. Over the past 20 years, researchers have studied how to help islet cells survive without antibodies suppressing their rejection in a recipient’s body. This would allow cells from a donor pancreas to be transplanted into the patient’s body without the toxic side effects of continuous immune suppressive therapy. New knowledge about the endocrine cell differentiation process has opened the possibility of generating large quantities of new islets from abundant sources of cells for transplantation. These include: • Human adult stem cells found in the pancreas • Embryonic human stem cells • Cells in the liver that can be converted into pancreatic cells • Derivatives of human fetal duct cells • Pancreatic progenitor cells found in the adult pancreas Researchers have had limited success in replicating pancreatic and islet cells, but few have survived and functioned properly in the bodies of patients. prompt: Do you have information about Kidney Transplantation
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Kidney transplantation is a procedure to replace a nonfunctioning kidney with a healthy kidney from another person. This is done to treat kidney failure, which is when your kidneys are able to no longer effectively ﬁlter toxins from your blood. In a kidney transplant procedure, a healthy kidney from a living or deceased donor is placed inside your lower abdomen, where the new kidney’s blood vessels are connected to your blood vessels. In general, the transplanted kidney takes over the task of ﬁltering your blood. It is possible you will need to continue dialysis until the new kidney starts to work. We will discuss the beneﬁts and risks of kidney transplantation. The following risks are associated with transplantation: • The new kidney may not work well. In this case, you will have to continue with dialysis. • You may have bleeding or problems related to anesthesia. • You may develop an infection. • Over time, your body may reject the new kidney.  You will need to take anti-rejection medicines. These medicines will suppress your immune system so that your body will not reject the new kidney. However, by suppressing your immune system, these medicines make it easier for your body to get infections and certain types of cancer. • You may develop diabetes. • In rare cases, you may die as a result of the surgery. If you have any questions about this procedure, please ask me. I ﬁnd it helpful to know what patients understand about kidney transplantation.  What have you been told about kidney transplantation? Medications have been given to reduce the chance of kidney rejection. I understand that these drugs must be taken for a lifetime. Are there any other medications that I should avoid? Are herbal supplements safe to take? I understand that my transplanted kidney may not last forever. If my new kidney fails at some time, then will I be eligible for another kidney transplant? {"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"INTRODUCTION  Men face more health risks and die at higher rates than women from the three biggest killers—heart disease, cancer, and stroke—as well as from all causes combined. Men’s life expectancy is substantially shorter, and the gap has continued to increase in recent years. Diseases related to tobacco use, high risk-taking behavior, and poor health care are important factors in this disparity. Moreover, men use medical services less frequently than women, contributing to the lower likelihood that many health problems will be detected early and treated effectively.  Aging is the most important risk factor for developing many serious illnesses. The health of older adults determines their ability to live independently and participate in society, as well as their need for social services. Men experience a more gradual increase in risk of health decline between midlife and oldest ages, while women show a rapid increase in risk in old-old age. In 2020, average life expectancy at birth was 75.1 years for men and 80.5 years for women.  Men experience high rates of illness from many chronic diseases and other health problems. For example, 50% more men than women have diabetes, and about 6 in 10 men have heart disease. Leading causes of death for men are as follows:  1. Heart disease (about 30% of male deaths in 2021)  2. Cancer (about 25%)  3. COVID-19 (about 6%)  4. Unintentional injuries (about 7%)  5. Stroke (about 5%) 6 Suicide (about 3%) 7 Chronic lower respiratory disease (about 3%) 8 Kidney disease (about 2%) 9 Alzheimer’s disease (about 2%) 10 Diabetes (about 2%) 11 Liver disease (about 1%) 12 Parkinson’s disease (about 1%) 13 Homicide (about 1%) 14 Hypertension (less than 1%) 15 Pneumonia and inﬂuenza (less than 1%)  The higher disease burden carried by men than by women places additional demands on the health care system and the workers in it, as well as on families and communities that provide unpaid care. Because the occupations of the two sexes differ substantially, most research on sex differences in health has not taken into account the workplace hazards to which men and women are disproportionately exposed.  Men’s Health Topics , Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Accessed June 2024.
